content.question:
Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.

An instructor at a large indoor cycling club believes that the amount of fluids that the <math alttext="425" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>425</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> members of the club consume, on average, per <math alttext="90" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>90</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>-minute class is different from <math alttext="24" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>24</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ounces. A random sample of <math alttext="35" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>35</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> members from the club were surveyed with the following question.

How many ounces of fluids do you usually consume per <math alttext="90" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>90</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>-minute class?

From the <math alttext="35" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>35</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> respondents, the instructor obtained a one-sample <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-interval to estimate <math alttext="mu sub F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, the mean amount of fluids, in ounces, that all members of the club consume per <math alttext="90" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>90</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>-minute class. Assume the conditions for inference have been met. At the <math alttext="99" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>99</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confidence level, the interval was <math alttext="30.556 plus or minus 4.076" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30.556</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>4.076</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Does the confidence interval support the instructor’s belief that the amount of fluids that all members of the club consume, on average, per <math alttext="90" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>90</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>-minute class is different from <math alttext="24" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>24</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ounces? Justify your answer.

frqParts.text:
Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.

An instructor at a large indoor cycling club believes that the amount of fluids that the <math alttext="425" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>425</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> members of the club consume, on average, per <math alttext="90" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>90</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>-minute class is different from <math alttext="24" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>24</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ounces. A random sample of <math alttext="35" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>35</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> members from the club were surveyed with the following question.

How many ounces of fluids do you usually consume per <math alttext="90" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>90</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>-minute class?

From the <math alttext="35" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>35</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> respondents, the instructor obtained a one-sample <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-interval to estimate <math alttext="mu sub F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, the mean amount of fluids, in ounces, that all members of the club consume per <math alttext="90" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>90</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>-minute class. Assume the conditions for inference have been met. At the <math alttext="99" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>99</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confidence level, the interval was <math alttext="30.556 plus or minus 4.076" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30.556</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>4.076</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Does the confidence interval support the instructor’s belief that the amount of fluids that all members of the club consume, on average, per <math alttext="90" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>90</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>-minute class is different from <math alttext="24" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>24</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ounces? Justify your answer.

Upon further investigation, the instructor thinks that members who consume sports drinks during a class may respond differently to the survey than members who consume water during a class. The instructor plans to conduct a new survey using independent random samples of members who consume sports drinks during a class and members who consume water during a class. Assume that there are approximately equal numbers of members who consume sports drinks during a class and members who consume water during a class.
(b) Describe a method that the instructor could use to obtain two independent random samples, one of <math alttext="15" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>15</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> members who consume sports drinks during a class and one of <math alttext="12" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> members who consume water during a class, from the <math alttext="425" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>425</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> members in the club.

(c) The instructor wants to use an inference procedure to determine whether the sample data provide convincing statistical evidence of a difference in the population mean amounts of fluids, in ounces, consumed per <math alttext="90" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>90</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>-minute class for members who would consume sports drinks and members who would consume water. Explain whether each condition for inference is met.

The instructor decided to also ask each member in the new survey to report the distance they typically cycle, in miles, in a <math alttext="90" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>90</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>-minute class. The scatterplot below shows the data for each of the members in the two samples.

(d) Describe what the scatterplot reveals about the relationship between distance cycled per class and fluids consumed per class for each of the following: the <math alttext="15" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>15</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> members who consume sports drinks during a class and the <math alttext="12" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> members who consume water during a class.

A scatterplot of only the <math alttext="15" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>15</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> members who consume sports drinks during a class is shown, along with regression output for a linear model using distance cycled per class to predict amount of fluids consumed per class.

(e) Describe the impact on the slope of the least-squares regression line and the coefficient of determination, <math alttext="r squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, if a member who reported <math alttext="16" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>16</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> miles cycled per class and <math alttext="40" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ounces of fluids consumed per class was added to the data. Explain your answer.

skill.text: Skill 1.C: Describe an appropriate method for gathering and representing data.
